subsection.title: Sequences
subsection.p: In the discussion above we used the term sequence without giving it a precise mathematical meaning. Let us rectify this now.

statement.p:
A sequence is a list of infinitely
For the more pedantic reader, here we mean a countably infinite list of numbers. The interested (pedantic or otherwise) reader should look up countable and uncountable sets.
many numbers with a specified order. It is denoted
\big\{a_1,\ a_2,\ a_3,\ \cdots,\ a_n,\ \cdots\big\} \quad\text{or}\quad \big\{a_n\big\} \quad\text{or}\quad \big\{a_n\big\}_{n=1}^\infty

subsection.p:
We will often specify a sequence by writing it more explicitly, like
\Big\{ a_n = f(n) \Big\}_{n=1}^\infty
where f(n) is some function from the natural numbers to the real numbers.

example.title: Three sequences and another one

subsection.p: Our primary concern with sequences will be the behaviour of a_n as n tends to infinity and, in particular, whether or not a_n settles down to some value as n tends to infinity.

statement.p:
A sequence \big\{a_n\big\}_{n=1}^\infty is said to converge to the limit A if a_n approaches A as n tends to infinity. If so, we write
\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty} a_n=A\qquad\hbox{or}\qquad a_n\rightarrow A\text{ as }n\rightarrow\infty
A sequence is said to converge if it converges to some limit. Otherwise it is said to diverge.

subsection.p:
The reader should immediately recognise the similarity with limits at infinity
\lim_{x \to \infty} f(x) = L \qquad\hbox{if}\qquad f(x) \to L \text{ as } x \to \infty

example.title: Convergence in Example
example.p:
Three of the four sequences in Example diverge:
The sequence \big\{a_n=n\big\}_{n=1}^\infty diverges because a_n grows without bound, rather than approaching some finite value, as n tends to infinity.
The sequence \big\{a_n=(-1)^{n-1}\big\}_{n=1}^\infty diverges because a_n oscillates between +1 and -1 rather than approaching a single value as n tends to infinity.
The sequence of the decimal digits of \pi also diverges, though the proof that this is the case is a bit beyond us right now
If the digits of \pi were to converge, then \pi would have to be a rational number. The irrationality of \pi (that it cannot be written as a fraction) was first proved by Lambert in 1761. Niven's 1947 proof is more accessible and we invite the interested reader to use their favourite search engine to find step-by-step guides to that proof.
.
The other sequence in Example has a_n=\frac{1}{n}. As n tends to infinity, \frac{1}{n} tends to zero. So
\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty} \frac{1}{n}=0

subsection.p: Notice that in this last example, we are really using techniques that we used before to study infinite limits like \ds \lim_{x\rightarrow\infty}f(x). This experience can be easily transferred to dealing with \lim\limits_{n\rightarrow\infty}a_n limits by using the following result.

statement.p:
If
\lim_{x\rightarrow\infty} f(x) = L
and if a_n=f(n) for all positive integers n, then
\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty} a_n = L

example.p:
Set f(x)=e^{-x}. Then e^{-n}=f(n) and
\text{since } \lim_{x\rightarrow\infty}e^{-x}&=0 &\text{ we know that }&& \lim\limits_{n\rightarrow\infty}e^{-n}&=0

subsection.p: The bulk of the rules for the arithmetic of limits of functions that you already know also apply to the limits of sequences. That is, the rules you learned to work with limits such as \ds \lim_{x\rightarrow\infty}f(x) also apply to limits like \ds\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}a_n.

statement.p:
Let A, B and C be real numbers and let the two sequences \big\{a_n\big\}_{n=1}^\infty and \big\{b_n\big\}_{n=1}^\infty converge to A and B respectively. That is, assume that
\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n&=A & \lim_{n \to \infty} b_n &=B
Then the following limits hold.
\ds \lim_{n \to \infty} \big[a_n+b_n\big] = A+B
(The limit of the sum is the sum of the limits.)
\ds \lim_{n \to \infty} \big[a_n-b_n\big] = A-B
(The limit of the difference is the difference of the limits.)
\ds \lim_{n \to \infty} C a_n = C A.
\ds \lim_{n \to \infty} a_n\,b_n = A\,B
(The limit of the product is the product of the limits.)
If B \neq 0 then \ds \lim_{n \to \infty}\frac{a_n}{b_n} = \frac{A}{B}
(The limit of the quotient is the quotient of the limits provided the limit of the denominator is not zero.)

subsection.p: We use these rules to evaluate limits of more complicated sequences in terms of the limits of simpler sequences just as we did for limits of functions.

example.title: Arithmetic of limits

subsection.p: There is also a squeeze theorem for sequences.

statement.p:
If a_n\le c_n\le b_n for all natural numbers n, and if
\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}a_n=\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}b_n=L
then
\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}c_n=L

example.title: A simple squeeze
example.p:
In this example we use the squeeze theorem to evaluate
\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\Big[1+\frac{\pi_n}{n}\Big]
where \pi_n is the n^{\mathrm{th}} decimal digit of \pi. That is,
\pi_1=3\quad \pi_2=1 \quad \pi_3=4 \quad \pi_4=1 \quad \pi_5=5 \quad\pi_6=9\quad\cdots
We do not have a simple formula for \pi_n. But we do know that
0\le\pi_n\le 9 \implies 0 \le \frac{\pi_n}{n} \le \frac{9}{n} \implies 1 \le 1+\frac{\pi_n}{n} \le 1+\frac{9}{n}
and we also know that
\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty} 1 = 1\qquad \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty} \Big[1+\frac{9}{n}\Big] = 1
So the squeeze theorem with a_n=1, b_n=1+\frac{\pi_n}{n}, and c_n=1+\frac{9}{n} gives
\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\Big[1+\frac{\pi_n}{n}\Big] = 1

subsection.p: Finally, recall that we can compute the limit of the composition of two functions using continuity. In the same way, we have the following result:

statement.p:
If \lim\limits_{n\rightarrow\infty}a_n=L and if the function g(x) is continuous at L, then
\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}g(a_n)=g(L)

subsection.p: With this introduction to sequences and some tools to determine their limits, we can now return to the problem of understanding infinite sums.
